intro: Acacia hova, commonly known as the white acacia, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to Madagascar. It is characterized by its slender, branching structure and small, feathery leaves that are often clustered at the ends of the stems. The plant produces yellow flowers in globular clusters, which are followed by long, flat pods containing seeds. Acacia hova is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it a hardy species in tropical and subtropical regions. It is also valued for its use in traditional medicine and as a source of timber and fuel.

This plant thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is commonly found in coastal and inland regions. It plays an important ecological role in its native habitat. Acacia hova is also known for its distinctive appearance and is sometimes cultivated for ornamental purposes.
